content: The Act titled "Sexual Offender Tracking and Identification Act of 1996" establishes the FBI Database for offender registration under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The Act establishes the FBI Database for offender registration, defining terms like 'FBI', 'criminal offense against a minor', 'sexually violent offense', and 'minimally sufficient sexual offender registration program'. The Attorney General will establish a national database at the FBI to track convicted offenders of crimes against minors, sexually violent offenses, and sexually violent predators. Offenders must register for at least 10 years after release from prison, parole, supervised release, or probation. The information may also be disclosed for community notification and employment-related background checks. SEC. 3. DURATION OF STATE REGISTRATION REQUIREMENT. Section 170101(b)(6) of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to specify that a person required to register under subsection (a)(1) must comply with the registration requirements for either 10 years after release from prison or for life if they have certain prior convictions or aggravated offenses. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 specifies that a person must comply with registration requirements for either 10 years after release from prison or for life if they have certain prior convictions or aggravated offenses, including being determined as a sexually violent predator. SEC. 4 amends the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 to include victim rights advocates and law enforcement representatives on state boards. SEC. 5 adds a requirement for submitting fingerprints when registering under the Act. SEC. 6 pertains to verification. SEC. 6 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 now requires individuals to include fingerprints and a photograph with their verification form. SEC. 7 mandates the Attorney General to issue regulations within a year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 8 states that the Act and its amendments will take effect one year after enactment, with states required to comply within three years, with a possible extension of two years for good faith efforts. SEC. 9 of the Act states that if any provision or application is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act, its amendments, and their application will not be affected.
